pr_title: kernel: KProveOptions: --concrete-rules is now implemented in front-end

timeline.bodyText: Architecturally, this is wrong. It should not require a KProveOptions object to construct something unless you are within the kprove tool's code path, but backends can also be constructed by kompile
timeline.author: dwightguth

replies.bodyText: Yes I'm aware of this. Actually there are other changes needed that will make access to KProveOptions unnecessary.
replies.author: denis-bogdanas

timeline.message: Replaced "concrete" string with Attribute.CONCRETE_KEY where possible.
KProveOptions: --concrete-rules is now implemented in front-end.

tests/concrete-function-cache - test exposing interaction between incorrect implementation of --concrete-rules in this PR and runtime definition cache (kserver mode).
ktest.mak: extension to allow $(DEF) in different directory. Required for this test.

tests/concrete-function-cache - test exposing interaction between incorrect implementation of --concrete-rules in this PR and runtime definition cache (kserver mode).
ktest.mak: extension to allow $(DEF) in different directory. Required for this test.
KProveOptions: --concrete-rules is now implemented in front-end. Entirely new implementation that doesn't depend on KProveOptions.
